Creatures

May 2012

A simulated landscape with food sources (in green) and threats (in red), populated with roaming, artificial creatures. The creatures forage for food, avoid danger, remember, reproduce, age, and die.

Each creature makes decisions depending on its location in the landscape. If the creature is near an unknown object, it will move towards it to examine it more closely. It will then feed or flee depending on what that object is - food, or a threat.

If the creature is near a potential mate, a fitness algorithm will decide whether or not the two creatures should reproduce. When they do, a new creature is born.

The project uses Reynolds' steering behaviours and genetic algorithms to give the different species of creatures their life-like behaviour.

Paul May is a researcher and designer from Dublin, living and working in London. See more of Paul's work or get in touch.
